predictpage.title: Disease Prediction
predictpage.alert: Please choose at least one symptom!

information.Fungal infection: Diseases caused by fungi affecting skin, nails, mucous membranes, lungs, or internal organs.
information.Allergy: An overreaction of the immune system to harmless substances like pollen, dust, or certain foods.
information.GERD: (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease), A chronic condition where stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing heartburn and irritation.
information.Chronic cholestasis: Long-term reduction or stoppage of bile flow, leading to accumulation of bile acids in the liver.
information.Drug Reaction: Adverse immune response to a medication, ranging from mild rashes to severe systemic reactions.
information.Peptic ulcer diseae: Open sores that develop on the inner lining of the stomach or upper small intestine, often due to H. pylori infection or NSAID use.
information.AIDS: (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome), Advanced stage of HIV infection characterized by a severely weakened immune system.
information.Diabetes: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels due to insulin deficiency or resistance.
information.Gastroenteritis: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines, leading to symptoms like diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps.
information.Bronchial Asthma: A chronic inflammatory disease of the airways causing episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness, and coughing.
information.Hypertension: (High Blood Pressure), A condition where the force of the blood against artery walls is consistently too high (â‰¥140/90 mmHg), increasing the risk of heart disease and stroke.
information.Migraine: A neurological condition characterized by intense, throbbing headaches, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.
information.Cervical spondylosis: Age-related wear and tear affecting the spinal disks in the neck, leading to stiffness and pain.
information.Paralysis (brain hemorrhage): Loss of muscle function due to bleeding in the brain, often resulting from a ruptured blood vessel.
information.Jaundice: Yellowing of the skin and eyes caused by elevated bilirubin levels, often indicating liver dysfunction.
information.Malaria: A mosquito-borne disease caused by Plasmodium parasites, leading to fever, chills, and flu-like symptoms.
information.Chicken pox: A highly contagious viral infection causing an itchy rash with red spots and blisters.
information.Dengue: A mosquito-transmitted viral infection causing high fever, rash, and muscle pain. Severe cases can lead to dengue hemorrhagic fever.
information.Typhoid: A bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi, spread through contaminated food and water.
information.Hepatitis A: A contagious liver infection caused by the hepatitis A virus, often transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food or water.
information.Hepatitis B: A viral infection that attacks the liver and can cause both acute and chronic disease.
information.Hepatitis C: A liver infection caused by the hepatitis C virus, often leading to chronic liver disease.
information.Hepatitis D: A liver infection caused by the hepatitis D virus, which only occurs in those infected with hepatitis B.
information.Hepatitis E: A liver disease caused by the hepatitis E virus, typically transmitted through contaminated water.
information.Alcoholic hepatitis: Inflammation of the liver caused by excessive alcohol consumption.
information.Tuberculosis: A contagious bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other organs.
information.Common Cold: A viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, causing symptoms like a runny nose, sore throat, and cough.
information.Pneumonia: An infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid.
information.Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles): Swollen veins in the lower rectum or anus, causing discomfort and bleeding.
information.Heart attack: Occurs when blood flow to a part of the heart is blocked, leading to damage or death of heart muscle.
information.Varicose veins: Swollen, twisted veins that are visible just under the surface of the skin, commonly occurring in the legs due to weakened vein walls and valves.
information.Hypothyroidism: A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones, leading to a slowdown in bodily functions.
information.Hyperthyroidism: A condition where the thyroid gland produces excessive thyroid hormones, accelerating the body's metabolism.
information.Hypoglycemia: A condition characterized by abnormally low blood sugar levels, often associated with diabetes treatment but can occur in non-diabetics as well.
information.Osteoarthristis: A degenerative joint disease where the cartilage that cushions the ends of bones wears down over time, causing pain and stiffness.
information.Arthritis: Inflammation of one or more joints, leading to pain and stiffness. There are various types, including osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.
information.(vertigo) Paroymsal Positional Vertigo: A disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear, leading to brief episodes of dizziness or vertigo triggered by changes in head position.
information.Acne: A skin condition where hair follicles become clogged with oil and dead skin cells, leading to pimples, blackheads, and whiteheads.
information.Urinary tract infection: An infection in any part of the urinary system, commonly the bladder and urethra, caused by bacteria.
information.Psoriasis: A chronic autoimmune skin disease that speeds up the life cycle of skin cells, leading to red patches covered with silvery scales.
information.Impetigo: A highly contagious bacterial skin infection, common in children, characterized by red sores that can rupture, ooze, and form a yellow-brown crust.

treatment.Fungal infection: Antifungal medications in topical (creams, ointments), oral (pills, liquids), or intravenous forms, depending on infection severity and location.
treatment.Allergy: Includes antihistamines, corticosteroids, decongestants, nasal sprays, and immunotherapy (allergy shots or sublingual tablets) to build tolerance.
treatment.GERD: Lifestyle changes (diet modification, weight loss), over-the-counter antacids, H2 blockers, proton pump inhibitors, and in severe cases, surgery.
treatment.Chronic cholestasis: Medications like ursodeoxycholic acid to improve bile flow, phenobarbital in some pediatric cases, and management of complications such as osteoporosis with bisphosphonates.
treatment.Drug Reaction: Immediate discontinuation of the offending drug, administration of antihistamines or corticosteroids for symptom relief, and in some cases, desensitization therapy.
treatment.Peptic ulcer diseae: Combination of antibiotics to eradicate H. pylori, proton pump inhibitors to reduce stomach acid, and lifestyle modifications.
treatment.AIDS: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) involving a combination of HIV medicines to control the virus, improve immune function, and reduce transmission risk.
treatment.Diabetes: Includes lifestyle changes (diet, exercise), blood sugar monitoring, oral medications, insulin therapy, and in some cases, pancreas transplantation.
treatment.Gastroenteritis: Supportive care with fluid and electrolyte replacement, rest, and, in some cases, medications to alleviate symptoms. Antibiotics are rarely needed.
treatment.Bronchial Asthma: Inhaled corticosteroids to reduce inflammation, bronchodilators for symptom relief, avoidance of triggers, and in severe cases, biologic therapies.
treatment.Hypertension: Lifestyle changes such as reducing sodium intake, regular exercise, and limiting alcohol. Medications may include diuretics, ACE inhibitors, or beta-blockers.
treatment.Migraine: Over-the-counter pain relievers, prescription medications like triptans, and preventive measures including lifestyle modifications and avoiding known triggers.
treatment.Cervical spondylosis: Physical therapy, pain relievers, and in severe cases, surgical intervention to relieve nerve compression.
treatment.Paralysis (brain hemorrhage): Emergency medical care to control bleeding and reduce pressure in the brain, followed by rehabilitation therapies.
treatment.Jaundice: Addressing the underlying cause, such as treating hepatitis or managing bile duct obstructions.
treatment.Malaria: Antimalarial medications like chloroquine or artemisinin-based combination therapies, depending on the parasite strain. Mayo Clinic
treatment.Chicken pox: Symptom relief through antihistamines and calamine lotion; vaccination is the best preventive measure.
treatment.Dengue: No specific treatment; supportive care includes hydration and pain relievers.
treatment.Typhoid: Antibiotic therapy is essential; vaccination and improved sanitation are key preventive measures.
treatment.Hepatitis A: Most cases resolve without treatment; vaccination is effective for prevention.
treatment.Hepatitis B: Acute: No specific treatment; supportive care includes rest, adequate nutrition, and fluids. Chronic: Treated with antiviral medications such as tenofovir or entecavir to suppress the virus and prevent liver damage.
treatment.Hepatitis C: Direct-acting antiviral (DAA) medications can cure most cases, typically within 8 to 12 weeks.
treatment.Hepatitis D: Pegylated interferon is the primary treatment, effective in about 30% of cases. New treatments like Bulevirtide have been approved in some regions.
treatment.Hepatitis E: Usually self-limiting; supportive care includes rest and hydration. In chronic cases, antiviral medications like ribavirin may be used.
treatment.Alcoholic hepatitis: Immediate cessation of alcohol intake is crucial. Corticosteroids may be prescribed in severe cases. Nutritional support and counseling are also important.
treatment.Tuberculosis: A combination of antibiotics taken over several months. Drug-resistant TB may require newer regimens like BPaLM, which shortens treatment duration.
treatment.Common Cold: No cure; treatment focuses on relieving symptoms through rest, hydration, and over-the-counter remedies.
treatment.Pneumonia: Depends on the cause; bacterial pneumonia is treated with antibiotics, while viral pneumonia may require antiviral medications. Severe cases may need hospitalization and supportive care.
treatment.Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles): Over-the-counter creams, warm baths, and dietary changes can alleviate symptoms. Procedures like rubber band ligation or surgical removal may be necessary for severe cases.
treatment.Heart attack: Immediate medical attention is critical. Treatments include medications, angioplasty, stenting, or surgery to restore blood flow.
treatment.Varicose veins: Lifestyle changes (e.g., exercise, leg elevation), compression stockings, and medical procedures like sclerotherapy, laser treatments, or surgical removal in severe cases.
treatment.Hypothyroidism: Daily intake of synthetic thyroid hormone levothyroxine to normalize hormone levels and alleviate symptoms.
treatment.Hyperthyroidism: Options include antithyroid medications, radioactive iodine therapy, beta-blockers to manage symptoms, and sometimes surgical removal of the thyroid gland.
treatment.Hypoglycemia: Immediate consumption of fast-acting carbohydrates (like glucose tablets or juice), adjusting diabetes medications, and addressing underlying causes in non-diabetic individuals.
treatment.Osteoarthristis: Includes physical therapy, medications (like pain relievers and anti-inflammatories), lifestyle modifications, and in severe cases, joint replacement surgery.
treatment.Arthritis: Depends on the type but may involve medications, physical therapy, lifestyle changes, and sometimes surgery to repair joint damage.
treatment.(vertigo) Paroymsal Positional Vertigo: Canalith repositioning maneuvers (like the Epley maneuver) performed by a healthcare professional to move the dislodged crystals in the inner ear to a position where they don't cause symptoms.
treatment.Acne: Over-the-counter topical treatments, prescription medications (like retinoids and antibiotics), hormonal therapies, and in severe cases, isotretinoin.
treatment.Urinary tract infection: Antibiotics to eliminate the infection, increased fluid intake, and preventive measures like proper hygiene practices.
treatment.Psoriasis: Topical treatments (like corticosteroids), phototherapy, and systemic medications (like biologics) to reduce inflammation and slow skin cell turnover.
treatment.Impetigo: Topical antibiotic ointments or creams; in more severe cases, oral antibiotics may be prescribed.
